docs.title: Travel Documents & Visas
docs.description: Citizens of countries in the Visa Waiver Program (VWP) must obtain an ESTA authorization before travel. Others will need to apply for a visa.
points: Apply for ESTA at least 72 hours before your flight.
Your passport must be an e-passport with a digital chip to use the VWP.
Be prepared for questioning by Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officers on arrival.
Keep a digital copy of your return ticket and accommodation details.

culture.title: Culture & Traditions
culture.description: The US is a melting pot of cultures, with regional identities varying widely. Americans are generally informal, friendly, and direct.
points: A firm handshake is a common greeting.
Customer service is a big deal; politeness to staff is expected.
Tipping is customary and expected in most service industries (15-20% is standard).
Punctuality is important for appointments and reservations.

safety.title: Safety & Precautions
safety.description: Safety varies greatly by neighborhood and city. Use common sense, be aware of your surroundings, and research areas before you visit.
points: Keep valuables out of sight and be cautious in crowded tourist spots.
The emergency number is 911 for police, fire, and medical assistance.
Be aware of your surroundings, especially at night or in unfamiliar areas.
In case of a police stop while driving, stay in your vehicle with your hands visible.

health.title: Health & Diseases
health.description: The US healthcare system is excellent but extremely expensive. Comprehensive travel insurance is an absolute necessity.
points: Travel insurance is not just recommended, it's essential. Medical bills can be astronomical.
Tap water is safe to drink in all cities.
Pharmacies (like CVS, Walgreens) sell over-the-counter medications, but many require a prescription.
For minor issues, consider visiting an 'Urgent Care' clinic instead of a hospital emergency room.

money.title: Money & Budget
money.description: The currency is the US Dollar (USD). Credit and debit cards are accepted almost everywhere. Carrying a small amount of cash is useful for small purchases.
points: Contactless payments (Apple Pay, Google Pay) are very common.
Sales tax is added at the register and varies by state and city.
ATMs are widely available.
A daily budget of $150-$250 is a good starting point for a mid-range trip, excluding accommodation.

connectivity.title: Connectivity & Transport
connectivity.description: The US is a car-centric country. Renting a car is often the best way to explore, except in large cities with good public transport like New York or Chicago.
points: Domestic flights are the primary way to travel between distant cities.
Ride-sharing services like Uber and Lyft are available in most towns and cities.
Public transportation systems vary dramatically in quality from city to city.
Getting an eSIM or a local SIM card (from T-Mobile or AT&T) is easy and provides good coverage.

adaptation.title: Adaptation & Mindset
adaptation.description: Distances are vast; don't underestimate travel times between locations. Be open to the diversity of landscapes and people.
points: Expect friendly but sometimes brief interactions. Small talk with strangers is common.
Portion sizes in restaurants are often very large.
The imperial system (miles, feet, Fahrenheit) is used, which can be confusing for visitors.
Americans are proud of their country and its diversity; be respectful in discussions about politics and culture.
